div1.ab: Consulate of the United States of America at Bathurst Gambia 15th December 1860
div1.p: Sir: My report of last year was upon the trade and the commerce of Gambua as shown by statistics of 1858. I now purpose to make the Returns of 1859, the basis of this annual report.
I have also the pleasure of adding the report from the district of Sierra Leone Henry Rder Esq. Consular Agent.

The year 1859 was not a favorable one to the commerce of Gambia. The crops were short; impor- tations were more limited than in the proceeding year and consequently the Customs revenue showed a defe- iency as compared with recent previsions years, and above all

Unfortunately many of the articles re- quired in legitimate commerceee are used also in the slave-trade, namely Rum, lumber, empty casks for palm oil and spice: many instances have occured where vessels pursuing a legitmate voyage have suffered detention and been subject to trial on suspicion of being slavers thereby breaking up the voyage and causing only loss to owners. I can mention two cases in this colony the "S.W. Nash" and the "Mary Varsey" and in Sierra Leone. The "Thomas Watson" and the "Carolina".

Bees-wax, the third article of export also shows a deficit of 25 tons, in comparison with 1858.
The quality of the Gambia Ground nut surpasses that of any produced, and the trade of the place depends very materially upon that feul.

In "Commercial Regulations" there is one important change nope, on the eighteenth of April 1860 a new Colonial ordinance was enacted relative to port changes: the partic- ulars of which are as follows: "Upon all ships, boats + vessels, canoes alone excepted, of more than five tons whether British or Foreign and whether registered or not in the port of Bathurst entering the River Gambia or employed or plying within the limits thereof a Quarantive fee of Twenty one shilings in each year on first entrance into the port of Bathurst. Provided always that all
vessels

vessels employed solely in the River Gambia shall not be liable to pay the Quarantive Fee. Upon all ships, boats, or vessels of more than fifteen/15/ tons whether British or Foreign + whether regis- tered or not in the port of Bathurst white solely employed within the River Gambia a duty of one shiling per ton, registered ton- nage shall be paid to the collector of customs on or before the 31st day of January for the earnest year: provided always that upon any such vessel proceedings tp pay the additional one shiling per ton.

All vessls over fifteen/ 15/ tons whether British or Foreign shall pay two shillings per registered ton once in every year. Vessels that have paid the one shillings + nine pence per ton (the former sake of tonage) during the current year shall
pay three pence additional to make up the two shillings".

Vessels of entering the River Gambia have for the past six years suffered much inconvenience from the fact that Bird Island at the month of the River + one of the principal points mentioned in the sailing has been gradually sinking and for three years has not been visible at high tides: there was formerly a Flag- staff on this island devoting the pilot station, which neighbors were particulary requested to note as a guide: all this has disappeared The pilots now remain in their boat anchored off the old side of the Island, Vessels approaching the entrance should endeavor to make the order or Red Beroy placed in 1859 on the Red Bank in five + a half (5 1/2) fathoms of water (mud) at the third hour of flood tide
